title: Split-biquaternion
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a split-biquaternion is a <a href="hypercomplex%20number">hypercomplex number</a> of the form
where "w", "x", "y", and "z" are <a href="split-complex%20number">split-complex number</a>s and i, j, and k multiply as in the <a href="quaternion%20group">quaternion group</a>. Since each <a href="coefficient">coefficient</a> "w", "x", "y", "z" spans two <a href="real%20number">real</a> <a href="dimension">dimension</a>s, the split-biquaternion is an element of an eight-dimensional <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a>. Considering that it carries a multiplication, this vector space is an <a href="algebra%20over%20a%20field">algebra</a> over the real field, or an <a href="algebra%20over%20a%20ring">algebra over a ring</a> where the split-complex numbers form the ring. This algebra was introduced by <a href="William%20Kingdon%20Clifford">William Kingdon Clifford</a> in an 1873 article for the <a href="London%20Mathematical%20Society">London Mathematical Society</a>. It has been repeatedly noted in mathematical literature since then, variously as a deviation in terminology, an illustration of the <a href="tensor%20product%20of%20algebras">tensor product of algebras</a>, and as an illustration of the <a href="direct%20sum%20of%20modules%23Direct%20sum%20of%20algebras">direct sum of algebras</a>.
The split-biquaternions have been identified in various ways by algebraists; see below.
